item.title: The end to Israel's subsidy for ultra-Orthodox who don't serve in army could imperil Netanyahu
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and The Associated Press
item.description: Israel’s Supreme Court on Thursday ordered an end to government subsidies for many ultra-Orthodox men who do not serve in the army — a blockbuster ruling that could have far-reaching consequences for the government and the tens of thousands of religious men who refuse to take part in mandatory military service.

media:content.media:text: Israek Ultra-Orthodox Jews War
media:content.media:description: Ultra-Orthodox Jewish men stand in front of pictures of Israeli hostages held in Gaza, at the Western Wall in Jerusalem on Jan. 10, 2024.

item.title: Evan Gershkovich's friend says the reporter is unbroken by his year in a notorious Russian jail
item.dc:creator: Andrea Mitchell and Yuliya Talmazan
item.description: It has been one year since the jailing of American Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich in Russia on charges of espionage.

media:content.media:text: Evan Gershkovich stands inside a defendants' cage at The Moscow City Court
media:content.media:description: Evan Gershkovich stands inside a defendants' cage at The Moscow City Court, on June 22, 2023.

media:content.media:text: Evan Gershkovich escorted from court in Moscow on Jan. 26, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Gershkovich, after losing an appeal against his arrest.

item.title: Sacre bleu! Camembert and brie 'on the verge of extinction,' French scientists warn
item.dc:creator: Josh Lederman and Briony Sowden
item.description: Camembert and Brie could disappear, scientists in France are warning, owing to a decline of strains of fungus that give them their unique tastes and textures.

media:content.media:credit: Andrew B. Myers for NBC News
media:content.media:text: A wheel of cheese shaped gravestone in a cemetery on a hill, engraved with "Brie."
A Normandy cow that provides milk for Camembert cheese at a farm near Isigny Sainte-Mere; a cheesemaker in Camembert.
media:content.media:description: A Normandy cow that provides milk for Camembert cheese at a farm near Isigny Sainte-Mere; a cheesemaker in Camembert.

media:content.media:text: Camembert cheeses are packed into boxes at the Isigny Sainte
media:content.media:description: Camembert cheeses are packaged at the Isigny Saint-Mere company in Normandy, France.

media:content.media:text: A statue of Marie Harel, born in 1761, invented camembert cheese; cars along the Tour de France route advertise Coeur de Lion camembert cheese in 2002.
media:content.media:description: Marie Harel, born in 1761, invented Camembert cheese; cars along the Tour de France advertise Coeur de Lion Camembert.

item.title: Syria reports Israeli airstrikes near Aleppo, world court orders action on Gaza famine
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The Syrian army says Israeli airstrikes early Friday near the northern city of Aleppo killed or wounded “a number of” people and caused damage.

media:content.media:text: Lebanon Israel Hezbollah
media:content.media:description: Hezbollah militants at a funeral in Lebanon's southern village of Adaysseh along the border with Israel earlier this month.

item.title: At a Ramadan meal, Palestinian Bedouin invite Jewish Israelis to the table
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva
item.description: THE NEGEV DESERT, Israel — As the sun set Sunday, a handful of people filed into a dining hall in a quiet village in the Negev desert for a shared iftar, the sunset meal that breaks the Ramadan fast, that hosts hoped would offer a small ray of intercommunal light at a time of intense divisions stoked by the deadly Israel-Hamas war.

media:content.media:text: Guests serves themselves food.
media:content.media:description: Guests around the iftar table at Muhammad Abu Qwaider's home in the Negev desert on Sunday night.

media:content.media:text: Huda Abu Obaid, center, and other guests, chat, while sitting.
media:content.media:description: Huda Abu Obaid, a member of the Negev Coexistence Forum for Civil Equality, center, and other guests during the iftar.

media:content.media:text: A detail shot of the table with dishes around a plate of dates.
media:content.media:description: A plate piled high with dates alongside other dishes.

media:content.media:text: Muhammad Abu Qwaider holding his daughter, Maisa.
media:content.media:description: Muhammad Abu Qwaider with his daughter, Maisa, in az-Zarnūg village, near a place where he said the Israeli government destroyed two houses.

media:content.media:text: Hissan Abu Qwaider prepares fresh pita bread
media:content.media:description: Muhammad's mother, Hissan Abu Qwaider, prepares fresh manakish with za'atar before the iftar.

media:content.media:text: Horses in az-Zarnūg village near where Muhammad Abu Qwaider said the Israeli government destroyed two of his brothers' houses.
media:content.media:description: Horses in az-Zarnūg village near where Muhammad Abu Qwaider said the Israeli government destroyed two of his brothers' houses.

media:content.media:text: A child plays in front of a home.
media:content.media:description: Solar panels on the roof of a home in az-Zarnūg village.

media:content.media:text: The only bomb shelter in az-Zarnūg village.
media:content.media:description: The only bomb shelter in az-Zarnūg village.

media:content.media:text: Haia Noach, co-founder of the Negev Coexistence Forum for Civil Equality, and Huda Abu Obaid, also a member of the forum.
media:content.media:description: Haia Noach, co-founder of the Negev Coexistence Forum for Civil Equality, and Huda Abu Obaid, also a member of the forum.

media:content.media:text: Gil Shohat poses for a photo.
media:content.media:description: Gil Shohat.

media:content.media:text: Young women chat during the iftar gathering in az-Zarnūg village.
media:content.media:description: Young women chat during the iftar gathering in az-Zarnūg village.

item.title: An airstrip is being built on a Yemeni island near the Red Sea with 'I LOVE UAE' next to it
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: As Yemen’s Houthi rebels continue to target ships, satellite pictures show what appears to be a new airstrip being built near the entrance to the Red Sea.

media:content.media:text: Satellite images shot for the AP appear to show workers have laid out "I LOVE UAE" next to the runway, an abbreviation for the United Arab Emirates.
media:content.media:description: The construction of an airstrip on Abd al-Kuri Island, Yemen, on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: However, satellite images shot for the AP appear to show workers have laid out "I LOVE UAE" next to the runway, an abbreviation for the United Arab Emirates.
media:content.media:description: No country has publicly claimed the active construction taking place this month on Abd al-Kuri Island, a barren stretch of land rising out of the Indian Ocean near the mouth of the Gulf of Aden.

item.title: U.S. and Israeli defense chiefs meet as tensions rise over war in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Mosheh Gains
item.description: s tensions rise between the two countries, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin met with his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv.
media:content.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv on Oct. 28, 2023.

media:content.media:text: Tensions between U.S. and Israel rise after U.N. ceasefire vote
media:content.media:description: The U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, abstained from Monday’s Security Council vote, which passed 14-0.

media:content.media:text: Rafaf offensive southern Gaza
media:content.media:description: A Palestinian child wounded by an Israeli bombardment is treated at a hospital in Gaza's southernmost city, Rafah.

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

media:content.media:text: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas conflict has spread beyond the Mideast
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and JoElla Carman and Jiachuan Wu
item.description: Four months into the war, fighting has spread from Gaza to Pakistan.

item.title: Department of Homeland Security working to stop illegal gun flow into Haiti
item.description: A U.N. report last year found most of the guns used by gangs in Haiti have been smuggled illegally from the U.S. NBC’s Guad Venegas got an exclusive look inside the Department of Homeland Security operation that’s working to stop the flow of those weapons.

media:content.media:title: Department of Homeland Security working to stop illegal gun flow into Haiti
media:content.media:description: A U.N. report last year found most of the guns used by gangs in Haiti have been smuggled illegally from the U.S. NBC’s Guad Venegas got an exclusive look inside the Department of Homeland Security operation that’s working to stop the flow of those weapons.

item.title: ‘Her blood has been wasted’: Bereaved Gazan mother shows rare anger with Hamas leadership
item.description: After another night of deadly airstrikes in Rafah, NBC News spoke to bereaved mother Umm Al-Saeed Al-Rifi whose openly-expressed anger with Hamas leaders is rarely heard in Gaza. “I will burn Hamas and the whole world for my daughter,” she said.

media:content.media:title: ‘Her blood has been wasted’: Bereaved Gazan mother shows rare anger with Hamas leadership
media:content.media:description: After another night of deadly airstrikes in Rafah, NBC News spoke to bereaved mother Umm Al-Saeed Al-Rifi whose openly-expressed anger with Hamas leaders is rarely heard in Gaza. “I will burn Hamas and the whole world for my daughter,” she said.

item.title: First anniversary of reporter Evan Gershkovich's detention in Russia
item.description: The Wall Street Journal marked the captivity of its reporter with a dramatic front page, with most of it left blank to decry Gershkovich's absence. NBC News' Andrea Mitchell reports on the prospects of a deal to get Gershkovich and other Americans freed.

media:content.media:title: First anniversary of reporter Evan Gershkovich's detention in Russia
media:content.media:description: The Wall Street Journal marked the captivity of its reporter with a dramatic front page, with most of it left blank to decry Gershkovich's absence. NBC News' Andrea Mitchell reports on the prospects of a deal to get Gershkovich and other Americans freed.

item.title: Rafah's Emirati Hospital sees rise in premature births and underweight neonates
item.description: Doctors at Rafah's Emirati Hospital in southern Gaza told an NBC News crew that premature births and pregnancy complications had increased since the outbreak of war between Israel and Hamas.

media:content.media:title: Rafah's Emirati Hospital sees rise in premature births and underweight neonates
media:content.media:description: Doctors at Rafah's Emirati Hospital in southern Gaza told an NBC News crew that premature births and pregnancy complications had increased since the outbreak of war between Israel and Hamas.

item.title: Radio Free Asia closes Hong Kong bureau, citing security law concerns
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Jett and Abigail Williams
item.description: Radio Free Asia is withdrawing from Hong Kong, the U.S.-funded media outlet said, citing rising concerns about press freedom in the Chinese territory.

media:content.media:text: Hong Kong China Handover
media:content.media:description: A man waving the Chinese flag in Hong Kong on July 1, 2022, to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the former British colony’s return to Chinese rule.

media:content.media:text: Hong Kong Protests Against China's Proposed Security Law
media:content.media:description: Pro-democracy supporters scuffling with riot police in Hong Kong in 2020.

item.title: Baltimore bridge crash brings scrutiny to contaminated fuel, an 'open secret' in shipping
item.dc:creator: Rich Schapiro and Jon Schuppe and Susan Carroll and Stella Kim and Rae Wang and Dawn Liu and Julia Jester
item.description: The cause of the Dali cargo ship's crash into the Key Bridge in Baltimore is not yet known, but it has focused attention on the problem of contaminated fuel.

media:content.media:text: Image: Baltimore's Francis Scott Key Bridge Collapses After Being Struck By Cargo Ship
media:content.media:description: The Dali ran into the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, Md., causing it to collapse.

item.title: Welsh rugby star Louis Rees-Zammit turns to NFL and signs with Kansas City Chiefs
item.dc:creator: Marlene Lenthang and Alexander Smith
item.description: Louis Rees-Zammit, the wicked fast Welsh rugby star and fan favorite, has made an extraordinary crossover to American football, signing a deal with the Kansas City Chiefs, the team announced Friday.

media:content.media:text: Louis Rees-Zammit
media:content.media:description: Louis Rees-Zammit of Gloucester Rugby during the match in London last year.

media:content.media:text: Wales' wing Louis Rees-Zammit is tackled by Argentina's flanker Marcos Kremer during the France 2023 Rugby World Cup quarter-final in Marseille, France, on Oct. 14, 2023.
media:content.media:description: Wales' wing Louis Rees-Zammit is tackled by Argentina's flanker Marcos Kremer during the World Cup quarter-final in Marseille, France, on Oct. 14, 2023.

item.title: Russia mulls labelling queen of Soviet pop, a foreign agent
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Russian prosecutors have asked the justice ministry to consider labelling Alla Pugacheva, the queen of Soviet pop music, as a “foreign agent.”

media:content.media:text: Russian President Vladimir Putin, left, and Russian pop singer Alla Pugacheva
media:content.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin and pop singer Alla Pugacheva at an awards ceremony in the Kremlin in Moscow in December 2014.

media:content.media:text: Singer Alla Pugacheva
media:content.media:description: Singer Alla Pugacheva at the farewell ceremony for former Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in March 2022.

item.title: A record surge in dengue cases in Latin America spurs a warning for proactive measures
item.dc:creator: Sandra Lilley
item.description: A record surge in dengue cases throughout Latin America and the Caribbean this year prompted the head of the Pan American Health Organization to call for collective action to curb the deadly mosquito-borne viral disease.

media:content.media:text: A health worker fumigates for mosquitoes inside a home to help mitigate the spread of dengue in the Las Penitas area of Talara, Peru on March 1, 2024.
media:content.media:description: A health worker fumigates for mosquitoes inside a home to help mitigate the spread of dengue in the Las Penitas area of Talara, Peru on March 1, 2024.

media:content.media:text: A man sits while waiting to be attended at a hospital.
media:content.media:description: A man who suffers from dengue symptoms waits to be attended to at a hospital amid a surge in cases nationwide, in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on Tuesday.

media:content.media:text: A worker fumigates a public school playground.
media:content.media:description: A health worker fumigates a public school playground as part of a campaign against dengue-promoting mosquitoes, in Brasilia, on March 9.

item.title: Mob beats to death suspected kidnapper in Mexico hours before Holy Week procession
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A mob in the Mexican tourist city of Taxco brutally beat a woman to death Thursday because she was suspected of kidnapping and killing a young girl, rampaging just hours before the city’s famous Holy Week procession.

media:content.media:text: People stand around a woman who was beaten by a mob that dragged her from a police vehicle under suspicion that she had participated in the kidnapping and killing of an 8-year-old girl in Taxco, Mexico, March 28, 2024. The woman died of her injuries.
media:content.media:description: People stand around a woman who was beaten by a mob that dragged her from a police vehicle Thursday under suspicion that she had participated in the kidnapping and killing of an 8-year-old girl in Taxco, Mexico. The woman died of her injuries.

media:content.media:text: A relative of an 8-year-old girl, who was kidnapped the previous day, weeps as her body is handed over to family in Taxco, Mexico, Thursday, March 28, 2024.
media:content.media:description: A relative of the kidnapped 8-year-old girl weeps Thursday as her body is handed over to family in Taxco.

media:content.media:text: Penitents carry a bundle of thorny branches during a Holy Week procession in Taxco, Mexico, Thursday, March 28, 2024.
media:content.media:description: Penitents carry a bundle of thorny branches during a Holy Week procession Thursday in Taxco.

item.title: 'Oppenheimer' finally premieres in Japan to mixed reactions and high emotions
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: “Oppenheimer” finally premiered Friday in Japan, the only nation to be attacked by the nuclear weapons invented by the American scientist who inspired the film.

media:content.media:text: “Oppenheimer” finally premiered Friday in the nation where two cities were obliterated 79 years ago by the nuclear weapons invented by the American scientist who was the subject of the Oscar-winning film.
media:content.media:description: An advertisment for the Academy Award winning film "Oppenheimer" in Tokyo on March 29, 2024.

item.title: Haiti gang leader 'Barbecue' would take part in peace talks but resist foreign peacekeepers
item.dc:creator: Patrick Smith
item.description: The gang leader who has become the face of Haiti's descent into lawlessness and violence has said he would consider calling a ceasefire only if his consortium of armed gangs was included in international talks on the country's future.

media:content.media:text: Haiti Experiences Surge Of Gang Violence
media:content.media:description: Haitian Gang Leader Jimmy 'Barbecue' Cherizier is flanked by his henchmen in Port-au-Prince on Feb. 22, 2024.

item.title: Owning Wrexham soccer team is hitting Ryan Reynolds in the wallet
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Owning Wrexham soccer club is hitting Ryan Reynolds in the wallet, accounts for the latest financial year show.

media:content.media:text: Wrexham v Boreham Wood - Vanarama National League
media:content.media:description: Wrexham co-owners Rob McElhenney and Ryan Reynolds lift the Vanarama National League Trophy in April.

item.title: Russian veto brings an end to the U.N. panel that monitors North Korea nuclear sanctions
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: A veto Thursday by Russia ended monitoring of U.N. sanctions against North Korea over its nuclear program.

media:content.media:text: Kim Putin Meeting Russia
media:content.media:description: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un shake hands with Russian President Vladiir Putin during their meeting at the Vostochny cosmodrome outside the city of Tsiolkovsky, Russia, on Sept. 13, 2023.
